trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET MVC app with auth and SQL DB and deploy to Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET MVC app with auth and SQL DB and deploy to Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to develop an ASP.NET MVC 5 app with a SQL Database back-end, add authentication and authorization, and deploy it to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to develop an ASP.NET MVC 5 app with a SQL Database back-end, add authentication and authorization, and deploy it to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET MVC app with auth and SQL DB and deploy to Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET MVC app with auth and SQL DB and deploy to Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to build a secure ASP.NET MVC 5 web app that enables users to log in with credentials from Facebook or Google.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to build a secure ASP.NET MVC 5 web app that enables users to log in with credentials from Facebook or Google.

trans-unit.source: You will also deploy the application to <link><linkText>App Service</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You will also deploy the application to <link><linkText>App Service</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can open an Azure account for free, and if you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK automatically installs Visual Studio 2013 for Web Express.
trans-unit.target: You can open an Azure account for free, and if you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK automatically installs Visual Studio 2013 for Web Express.

trans-unit.source: You can start developing for Azure for free.
trans-unit.target: You can start developing for Azure for free.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you have no prior experience using Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you have no prior experience using Azure.

trans-unit.source: On completing this tutorial, you'll have a secure data-driven web application up and running in the cloud and using a cloud database.
trans-unit.target: On completing this tutorial, you'll have a secure data-driven web application up and running in the cloud and using a cloud database.

trans-unit.source: You'll learn:
trans-unit.target: You'll learn:

trans-unit.source: How to create a secure ASP.NET MVC 5 project and publish it to <link><linkText>App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title></link> in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: How to create a secure ASP.NET MVC 5 project and publish it to <link><linkText>App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title></link> in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: How to use <link><linkText>OAuth</linkText><title>http://oauth.net/</title></link> and the ASP.NET membership database to secure your application.
trans-unit.target: How to use <link><linkText>OAuth</linkText><title>http://oauth.net/</title></link> and the ASP.NET membership database to secure your application.

trans-unit.source: How to use a SQL database to store data in Azure.
trans-unit.target: How to use a SQL database to store data in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You'll build a simple contact list web app that is built on ASP.NET MVC 5 and uses the ADO.NET Entity Framework for database access.
trans-unit.target: You'll build a simple contact list web app that is built on ASP.NET MVC 5 and uses the ADO.NET Entity Framework for database access.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows the login page for the completed application:
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows the login page for the completed application:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>login page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>login page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To create the pretty social login buttons in the screenshot above, please view the blog post entitled <link><linkText>Pretty social login buttons for ASP.NET MVC 5</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: To create the pretty social login buttons in the screenshot above, please view the blog post entitled <link><linkText>Pretty social login buttons for ASP.NET MVC 5</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can <link><linkText>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>sign up for a free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can <link><linkText>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>sign up for a free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: To set up your development environment, you must install <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2013 Update 4</linkText><title></title></link> or higher, and the latest version of the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title></link>. This article was written for Visual Studio Update 4 and SDK 2.5.1.
trans-unit.target: To set up your development environment, you must install <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2013 Update 4</linkText><title></title></link> or higher, and the latest version of the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title></link>. This article was written for Visual Studio Update 4 and SDK 2.5.1.

trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET MVC 5 application
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET MVC 5 application

trans-unit.source: Create the project
trans-unit.target: Create the project

trans-unit.source: From the File menu, click New Project.
trans-unit.target: From the File menu, click New Project.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New Project in File menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New Project in File menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, expand C# and select Web under Installed Templates, and then select ASP.NET Web Application.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, expand C# and select Web under Installed Templates, and then select ASP.NET Web Application.

trans-unit.source: Name the application ContactManager and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Name the application ContactManager and click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New Project dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New Project dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note: Make sure you enter "ContactManager".
trans-unit.target: Note: Make sure you enter "ContactManager".

trans-unit.source: Code blocks that you'll be copying later assume that the project name is ContactManager.
trans-unit.target: Code blocks that you'll be copying later assume that the project name is ContactManager.

trans-unit.source: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog box, select the MVC template.
trans-unit.target: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog box, select the MVC template.

trans-unit.source: Verify Authentication is set to Individual User Accounts, Host in the cloud is checked and Web App is selected.
trans-unit.target: Verify Authentication is set to Individual User Accounts, Host in the cloud is checked and Web App is selected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New ASP.NET Project dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New ASP.NET Project dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The configuration wizard will suggest a unique name based on ContactManager.
trans-unit.target: The configuration wizard will suggest a unique name based on ContactManager.

trans-unit.source: You must decide whether to create a new App Service plan and resource group.
trans-unit.target: You must decide whether to create a new App Service plan and resource group.

trans-unit.source: For guidance on deciding whether to create a new plan or resource group, see <link><linkText>Azure App Service plans in-depth overview</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For guidance on deciding whether to create a new plan or resource group, see <link><linkText>Azure App Service plans in-depth overview</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, you will probably want to create at least a new resource group.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, you will probably want to create at least a new resource group.

trans-unit.source: Select a region near you.
trans-unit.target: Select a region near you.

trans-unit.source: You can use <link><linkText>azurespeed.com</linkText><title>AzureSpeed.com</title></link> to find the lowest latency data center.
trans-unit.target: You can use <link><linkText>azurespeed.com</linkText><title>AzureSpeed.com</title></link> to find the lowest latency data center.

trans-unit.source: You will set up the database in the next step so do not click OK yet.
trans-unit.target: You will set up the database in the next step so do not click OK yet.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New plan and resource group</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New plan and resource group</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you haven't created a database server before, select Create new server, enter a database name, user name, and password.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't created a database server before, select Create new server, enter a database name, user name, and password.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Use new database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Use new database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you have a database server, use that to create a new database.
trans-unit.target: If you have a database server, use that to create a new database.

trans-unit.source: Database servers are a precious resource, and you generally want to create multiple databases on the same server for testing and development rather than creating a database server per database.
trans-unit.target: Database servers are a precious resource, and you generally want to create multiple databases on the same server for testing and development rather than creating a database server per database.

trans-unit.source: Make sure your web app and database are in the same region.
trans-unit.target: Make sure your web app and database are in the same region.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Use exsiting database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Use exsiting database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Set the page header and footer
trans-unit.target: Set the page header and footer

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer open the Layout.cshtml file in the Views\Shared folder.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer open the Layout.cshtml file in the Views\Shared folder.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>_Layout.cshtml in Solution Explorer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>_Layout.cshtml in Solution Explorer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace the markup in the Layout.cshtml file with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the markup in the Layout.cshtml file with the following code.

trans-unit.source: The changes are highlighted below.
trans-unit.target: The changes are highlighted below.

trans-unit.source: Run the application locally
trans-unit.target: Run the application locally

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+F5 to run the app.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to run the app.

trans-unit.source: The application home page appears in the default browser.
trans-unit.target: The application home page appears in the default browser.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web app running locally</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web app running locally</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This is all you need to do for now to create the application that you'll deploy to Azure.
trans-unit.target: This is all you need to do for now to create the application that you'll deploy to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Enable SSL for the Project
trans-unit.target: Enable SSL for the Project

trans-unit.source: Enable SSL.
trans-unit.target: Enable SSL.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, click the ContactManager project, then click F4 to bring up the properties dialog.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, click the ContactManager project, then click F4 to bring up the properties dialog.

trans-unit.source: Change SSL Enabled to true.
trans-unit.target: Change SSL Enabled to true.

trans-unit.source: Copy the SSL URL.
trans-unit.target: Copy the SSL URL.

trans-unit.source: The SSL URL will be https://localhost:44300/ unless you've previously created SSL web apps.
trans-unit.target: The SSL URL will be https://localhost:44300/ unless you've previously created SSL web apps.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>enable SSL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>enable SSL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click the Contact Manager project and click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click the Contact Manager project and click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the left tab, click Web.
trans-unit.target: In the left tab, click Web.

trans-unit.source: Change the Project Url to use the SSL URL and save the page (Control S).
trans-unit.target: Change the Project Url to use the SSL URL and save the page (Control S).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>enable SSL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>enable SSL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Verify Internet Explorer is the browser Visual Studio launches as shown in the image below:
trans-unit.target: Verify Internet Explorer is the browser Visual Studio launches as shown in the image below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>default browser</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>default browser</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The browser selector lets you specify the browser Visual Studio launches.
trans-unit.target: The browser selector lets you specify the browser Visual Studio launches.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>browser selector</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>browser selector</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can select multiple browsers and have Visual Studio update each browser when you make changes.
trans-unit.target: You can select multiple browsers and have Visual Studio update each browser when you make changes.

trans-unit.source: For more information see <link><linkText>Using Browser Link in Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information see <link><linkText>Using Browser Link in Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions to trust the self-signed certificate that IIS Express has generated.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions to trust the self-signed certificate that IIS Express has generated.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>instructions to trust the self-signed certificate that IIS Express has generated</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>instructions to trust the self-signed certificate that IIS Express has generated</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Read the Security Warning dialog and then click Yes if you want to install the certificate representing localhost.
trans-unit.target: Read the Security Warning dialog and then click Yes if you want to install the certificate representing localhost.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>localhost IIS Express certificate warning </linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>localhost IIS Express certificate warning </linkText>

trans-unit.source: IE shows the Home page and there are no SSL warnings.
trans-unit.target: IE shows the Home page and there are no SSL warnings.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>IE with localhost SSL and no warnings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>IE with localhost SSL and no warnings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Google Chrome also accepts the certificate and will show HTTPS content without a warning.
trans-unit.target: Google Chrome also accepts the certificate and will show HTTPS content without a warning.

trans-unit.source: Firefox uses its own certificate store, so it will display a warning.
trans-unit.target: Firefox uses its own certificate store, so it will display a warning.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>FireFox Cert Warning</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>FireFox Cert Warning</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Deploy the application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy the application to Azure

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish from the context menu.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish from the context menu.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish in project context menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish in project context menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Publish Web wizard opens.
trans-unit.target: The Publish Web wizard opens.

trans-unit.source: In the Publish Web dialog box, click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In the Publish Web dialog box, click Publish.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The application you created is now running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: The application you created is now running in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: The next time you deploy the application, only the changed (or new) files will be deployed.
trans-unit.target: The next time you deploy the application, only the changed (or new) files will be deployed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Running in Cloud</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Running in Cloud</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add a database to the application
trans-unit.target: Add a database to the application

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll update the app to add the ability to display and update contacts and store the data in a database.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll update the app to add the ability to display and update contacts and store the data in a database.

trans-unit.source: The app will use the Entity Framework (EF) to create the database and to read and update data.
trans-unit.target: The app will use the Entity Framework (EF) to create the database and to read and update data.

trans-unit.source: Add data model classes for the contacts
trans-unit.target: Add data model classes for the contacts

trans-unit.source: You begin by creating a simple data model in code.
trans-unit.target: You begin by creating a simple data model in code.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Models folder, click Add, and then Class.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Models folder, click Add, and then Class.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Class in Models folder context menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Class in Models folder context menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Item dialog box, name the new class file Contact.cs, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Item dialog box, name the new class file Contact.cs, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add New Item dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add New Item dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of the Contacts.cs file with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of the Contacts.cs file with the following code.

trans-unit.source: The Contacts class defines the data that you will store for each contact, plus a primary key, ContactID, that is needed by the database.
trans-unit.target: The Contacts class defines the data that you will store for each contact, plus a primary key, ContactID, that is needed by the database.

trans-unit.source: Create web pages that enable app users to work with the contacts
trans-unit.target: Create web pages that enable app users to work with the contacts

trans-unit.source: The ASP.NET MVC scaffolding feature can automatically generate code that performs create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) actions.
trans-unit.target: The ASP.NET MVC scaffolding feature can automatically generate code that performs create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) actions.

trans-unit.source: Add a Controller and a view for the data
trans-unit.target: Add a Controller and a view for the data

trans-unit.source: Build the project (Ctrl+Shift+B).
trans-unit.target: Build the project (Ctrl+Shift+B).

trans-unit.source: (You must build the project before using the scaffolding mechanism.)
trans-unit.target: (You must build the project before using the scaffolding mechanism.)

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Controllers folder and click Add, and then click Controller.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Controllers folder and click Add, and then click Controller.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Controller in Controllers folder context menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Controller in Controllers folder context menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Add Scaffold dialog box, select MVC 5 Controller with views, using EF and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Scaffold dialog box, select MVC 5 Controller with views, using EF and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Scaffold dlg</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Scaffold dlg</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Model class dropdown box, select Contact (ContactManager.Models).
trans-unit.target: In the Model class dropdown box, select Contact (ContactManager.Models).

trans-unit.source: (See the image below.)
trans-unit.target: (See the image below.)

trans-unit.source: In the Data context class, select ApplicationDbContext (ContactManager.Models).
trans-unit.target: In the Data context class, select ApplicationDbContext (ContactManager.Models).

trans-unit.source: The ApplicationDbContext will be used for both the membership DB and our contact data.
trans-unit.target: The ApplicationDbContext will be used for both the membership DB and our contact data.

trans-unit.source: In the Controller name text entry box, enter "CmController" for the controller name.
trans-unit.target: In the Controller name text entry box, enter "CmController" for the controller name.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New data ctx dlg</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New data ctx dlg</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click Add.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio creates a controller methods and views for CRUD database operations for Contact objects.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio creates a controller methods and views for CRUD database operations for Contact objects.

trans-unit.source: Enable Migrations, create the database, add sample data and a data initializer
trans-unit.target: Enable Migrations, create the database, add sample data and a data initializer

trans-unit.source: The next task is to enable the <link><linkText>Code First Migrations</linkText><title></title></link> feature in order to create the database based on the data model you created.
trans-unit.target: The next task is to enable the <link><linkText>Code First Migrations</linkText><title></title></link> feature in order to create the database based on the data model you created.

trans-unit.source: In the Tools menu, select NuGet Package Manager and then Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: In the Tools menu, select NuGet Package Manager and then Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Package Manager Console in Tools menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Package Manager Console in Tools menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console window, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console window, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: The enable-migrations command creates a Migrations folder, and it puts in that folder a Configuration.cs file that you can edit to seed the database and configure Migrations.
trans-unit.target: The enable-migrations command creates a Migrations folder, and it puts in that folder a Configuration.cs file that you can edit to seed the database and configure Migrations.

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console window, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console window, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: The add-migration Initial command generates a file named Initial in the Migrations folder that creates the database.
trans-unit.target: The add-migration Initial command generates a file named Initial in the Migrations folder that creates the database.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter ( Initial ) is arbitrary and is used to create the name of the file.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter ( Initial ) is arbitrary and is used to create the name of the file.

trans-unit.source: You can see the new class files in Solution Explorer.
trans-unit.target: You can see the new class files in Solution Explorer.

trans-unit.source: In the Initial class, the Up method creates the Contacts table, and the Down method (used when you want to return to the previous state) drops it.
trans-unit.target: In the Initial class, the Up method creates the Contacts table, and the Down method (used when you want to return to the previous state) drops it.

trans-unit.source: Open the Migrations\Configuration.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Open the Migrations\Configuration.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Add the following namespace.
trans-unit.target: Add the following namespace.

trans-unit.source: Replace the Seed method with the following code:
trans-unit.target: Replace the Seed method with the following code:

trans-unit.source: This code initializes (seeds) the database with the contact information.
trans-unit.target: This code initializes (seeds) the database with the contact information.

trans-unit.source: For more information on seeding the database, see <link><linkText>Seeding and Debugging Entity Framework (EF) DBs</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on seeding the database, see <link><linkText>Seeding and Debugging Entity Framework (EF) DBs</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console enter the command:
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console enter the command:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Package Manager Console commands</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Package Manager Console commands</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The update-database runs the first migration which creates the database.
trans-unit.target: The update-database runs the first migration which creates the database.

trans-unit.source: By default, the database is created as a SQL Server Express LocalDB database.
trans-unit.target: By default, the database is created as a SQL Server Express LocalDB database.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application, and then click the CM Demo link; or navigate to https://localhost:(port#)/Cm.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application, and then click the CM Demo link; or navigate to https://localhost:(port#)/Cm.

trans-unit.source: The application shows the seed data and provides edit, details and delete links.
trans-unit.target: The application shows the seed data and provides edit, details and delete links.

trans-unit.source: You can create, edit, delete and view data.
trans-unit.target: You can create, edit, delete and view data.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>MVC view of data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>MVC view of data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add an OAuth2 Provider
trans-unit.target: Add an OAuth2 Provider

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>OAuth</linkText><title>http://oauth.net/</title></link> is an open protocol that allows secure authorization in a simple and standard method from web, mobile, and desktop applications.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>OAuth</linkText><title>http://oauth.net/</title></link> is an open protocol that allows secure authorization in a simple and standard method from web, mobile, and desktop applications.

trans-unit.source: The ASP.NET MVC internet template uses OAuth to expose Facebook, Twitter, Google and Microsoft as authentication providers.
trans-unit.target: The ASP.NET MVC internet template uses OAuth to expose Facebook, Twitter, Google and Microsoft as authentication providers.

trans-unit.source: Although this tutorial uses only Google as the authentication provider, you can easily modify the code to use any of these providers.
trans-unit.target: Although this tutorial uses only Google as the authentication provider, you can easily modify the code to use any of these providers.

trans-unit.source: The steps to implement other providers are very similar to the steps you will see in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The steps to implement other providers are very similar to the steps you will see in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: To use Facebook as an authentication provider, see my tutorial <link><linkText>MVC 5 App with Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google OAuth2 Sign-on </linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To use Facebook as an authentication provider, see my tutorial <link><linkText>MVC 5 App with Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google OAuth2 Sign-on </linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In addition to authentication, the tutorial will also use roles to implement authorization.
trans-unit.target: In addition to authentication, the tutorial will also use roles to implement authorization.

trans-unit.source: Only those users you add to the canEdit role will be able to change data (that is, create, edit, or delete contacts).
trans-unit.target: Only those users you add to the canEdit role will be able to change data (that is, create, edit, or delete contacts).

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions in my tutorial MVC 5 App with Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google OAuth2 Sign-on under Creating a Google app for OAuth 2 to set up a Google app for OAuth2.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions in my tutorial MVC 5 App with Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google OAuth2 Sign-on under Creating a Google app for OAuth 2 to set up a Google app for OAuth2.

trans-unit.source: Run and test the app to verify you can log on using Google authentication.
trans-unit.target: Run and test the app to verify you can log on using Google authentication.

trans-unit.source: Using the Membership API
trans-unit.target: Using the Membership API

trans-unit.source: In this section you will add a local user and the canEdit role to the membership database.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will add a local user and the canEdit role to the membership database.

trans-unit.source: Only those users in the canEdit role will be able to edit data.
trans-unit.target: Only those users in the canEdit role will be able to edit data.

trans-unit.source: A best practice is to name roles by the actions they can perform, so canEdit is preferred over a role called admin.
trans-unit.target: A best practice is to name roles by the actions they can perform, so canEdit is preferred over a role called admin.

trans-unit.source: When your application evolves you can add new roles such as canDeleteMembers rather than the less descriptive superAdmin.
trans-unit.target: When your application evolves you can add new roles such as canDeleteMembers rather than the less descriptive superAdmin.

trans-unit.source: Open the migrations\configuration.cs file and add the following using statements:
trans-unit.target: Open the migrations\configuration.cs file and add the following using statements:

trans-unit.source: Add the following AddUserAndRole method to the class:
trans-unit.target: Add the following AddUserAndRole method to the class:

trans-unit.source: Call the new method from the Seed method:
trans-unit.target: Call the new method from the Seed method:

trans-unit.source: The following images shows the changes to Seed method:
trans-unit.target: The following images shows the changes to Seed method:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>code image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>code image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This code creates a new role called canEdit, creates a new local user user1@contoso.com, and adds user1@contoso.com to the canEdit role.
trans-unit.target: This code creates a new role called canEdit, creates a new local user user1@contoso.com, and adds user1@contoso.com to the canEdit role.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see my <link><linkText>ASP.NET Identity tutorials</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see my <link><linkText>ASP.NET Identity tutorials</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Use Temporary Code to Add New Social Login Users to the canEdit Role
trans-unit.target: Use Temporary Code to Add New Social Login Users to the canEdit Role

trans-unit.source: In this section you will temporarily modify the ExternalLoginConfirmation method in the Account controller to add new users registering with an OAuth provider to the canEdit role.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will temporarily modify the ExternalLoginConfirmation method in the Account controller to add new users registering with an OAuth provider to the canEdit role.

trans-unit.source: We will temporarily modify the ExternalLoginConfirmation method to automatically add new users to an administrative role.
trans-unit.target: We will temporarily modify the ExternalLoginConfirmation method to automatically add new users to an administrative role.

trans-unit.source: Until we provide a tool to add and manage roles, we'll use the temporary automatic registration code below.
trans-unit.target: Until we provide a tool to add and manage roles, we'll use the temporary automatic registration code below.

trans-unit.source: We hope to provide a tool similar to <link><linkText>WSAT</linkText><title></title></link> in the future which allow you to create and edit user accounts and roles.
trans-unit.target: We hope to provide a tool similar to <link><linkText>WSAT</linkText><title></title></link> in the future which allow you to create and edit user accounts and roles.

trans-unit.source: Open the Controllers\AccountController.cs file and navigate to the ExternalLoginConfirmation method.
trans-unit.target: Open the Controllers\AccountController.cs file and navigate to the ExternalLoginConfirmation method.

trans-unit.source: Add the following call to AddToRoleAsync just before the SignInAsync call.
trans-unit.target: Add the following call to AddToRoleAsync just before the SignInAsync call.

trans-unit.source: The code above adds the newly registered user to the "canEdit" role, which gives them access to action methods that change (edit) data.
trans-unit.target: The code above adds the newly registered user to the "canEdit" role, which gives them access to action methods that change (edit) data.

trans-unit.source: Later in the tutorial you will deploy the application to Azure, where you will log-on with Google or another third party authentication provider.
trans-unit.target: Later in the tutorial you will deploy the application to Azure, where you will log-on with Google or another third party authentication provider.

trans-unit.source: This will add your newly registered account to the canEdit role.
trans-unit.target: This will add your newly registered account to the canEdit role.

trans-unit.source: Anyone who finds your web app's URL and has a Google ID can then register and update your database.
trans-unit.target: Anyone who finds your web app's URL and has a Google ID can then register and update your database.

trans-unit.source: To prevent other people from doing that, you can stop the site.
trans-unit.target: To prevent other people from doing that, you can stop the site.

trans-unit.source: You'll be able to verify who is in the canEdit role by examining the database.
trans-unit.target: You'll be able to verify who is in the canEdit role by examining the database.

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console hit the up arrow key to bring up the following command:
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console hit the up arrow key to bring up the following command:

trans-unit.source: Run the Update-Database command which will run the Seed method, and that will run the AddUserAndRole you just added.
trans-unit.target: Run the Update-Database command which will run the Seed method, and that will run the AddUserAndRole you just added.

trans-unit.source: The AddUserAndRole will create the user user1@contoso.com and add her to the canEdit role.
trans-unit.target: The AddUserAndRole will create the user user1@contoso.com and add her to the canEdit role.

trans-unit.source: Protect the Application with SSL and the Authorize Attribute
trans-unit.target: Protect the Application with SSL and the Authorize Attribute

trans-unit.source: In this section you will apply the <link><linkText>Authorize</linkText><title></title></link> attribute to restrict access to the action methods.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will apply the <link><linkText>Authorize</linkText><title></title></link> attribute to restrict access to the action methods.

trans-unit.source: Anonymous users will be able to view the Index action method of the home controller only.
trans-unit.target: Anonymous users will be able to view the Index action method of the home controller only.

trans-unit.source: Registered users will be able to see contact data (The Index and Details pages of the Cm controller), the About, and the Contact pages.
trans-unit.target: Registered users will be able to see contact data (The Index and Details pages of the Cm controller), the About, and the Contact pages.

trans-unit.source: Only users in the canEdit role will be able to access action methods that change data.
trans-unit.target: Only users in the canEdit role will be able to access action methods that change data.

trans-unit.source: Add the <link><linkText>Authorize</linkText><title></title></link> filter and the <link><linkText>RequireHttps</linkText><title></title></link> filter to the application.
trans-unit.target: Add the <link><linkText>Authorize</linkText><title></title></link> filter and the <link><linkText>RequireHttps</linkText><title></title></link> filter to the application.

trans-unit.source: An alternative approach is to add the <link><linkText>Authorize</linkText><title></title></link> attribute and the <link><linkText>RequireHttps</linkText><title></title></link> attribute to each controller, but it's considered a security best practice to apply them to the entire application.
trans-unit.target: An alternative approach is to add the <link><linkText>Authorize</linkText><title></title></link> attribute and the <link><linkText>RequireHttps</linkText><title></title></link> attribute to each controller, but it's considered a security best practice to apply them to the entire application.

trans-unit.source: By adding them globally, every new controller and action method you add will automatically be protected, you won't need to remember to apply them.
trans-unit.target: By adding them globally, every new controller and action method you add will automatically be protected, you won't need to remember to apply them.

trans-unit.source: For more information see <link><linkText>Securing your ASP.NET MVC App and the new AllowAnonymous Attribute</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information see <link><linkText>Securing your ASP.NET MVC App and the new AllowAnonymous Attribute</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Open the App_Start\FilterConfig.cs file and replace the RegisterGlobalFilters method with the following (which adds the two filters):
trans-unit.target: Open the App_Start\FilterConfig.cs file and replace the RegisterGlobalFilters method with the following (which adds the two filters):

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>Authorize</linkText><title></title></link> filter applied in the code above will prevent anonymous users from accessing any methods in the application.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>Authorize</linkText><title></title></link> filter applied in the code above will prevent anonymous users from accessing any methods in the application.

trans-unit.source: You will use the <link><linkText>AllowAnonymous</linkText><title></title></link> attribute to opt out of the authorization requirement in a couple methods, so anonymous users can log in and can view the home page.
trans-unit.target: You will use the <link><linkText>AllowAnonymous</linkText><title></title></link> attribute to opt out of the authorization requirement in a couple methods, so anonymous users can log in and can view the home page.

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>RequireHttps</linkText><title></title></link> will require all access to the web app be through HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>RequireHttps</linkText><title></title></link> will require all access to the web app be through HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: Add the AllowAnonymous attribute to the Index method of the Home controller.
trans-unit.target: Add the AllowAnonymous attribute to the Index method of the Home controller.

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>AllowAnonymous</linkText><title></title></link> attribute enables you to white-list the methods you want to opt out of authorization.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>AllowAnonymous</linkText><title></title></link> attribute enables you to white-list the methods you want to opt out of authorization.

trans-unit.source: Do a global search for AllowAnonymous, you can see it is used in the log in and registration methods of the Account controller.
trans-unit.target: Do a global search for AllowAnonymous, you can see it is used in the log in and registration methods of the Account controller.

trans-unit.source: In CmController.cs, add [Authorize(Roles = "canEdit")] to the HttpGet and HttpPost methods that change data (Create, Edit, Delete, every action method except Index and Details) in the Cm controller.
trans-unit.target: In CmController.cs, add [Authorize(Roles = "canEdit")] to the HttpGet and HttpPost methods that change data (Create, Edit, Delete, every action method except Index and Details) in the Cm controller.

trans-unit.source: A portion of the completed code is shown below:
trans-unit.target: A portion of the completed code is shown below:

trans-unit.source: If you are still logged in from a previous session, hit the Log out link.
trans-unit.target: If you are still logged in from a previous session, hit the Log out link.

trans-unit.source: Click on the About or Contact links.
trans-unit.target: Click on the About or Contact links.

trans-unit.source: You will be redirected to the log in page because anonymous users cannot view those pages.
trans-unit.target: You will be redirected to the log in page because anonymous users cannot view those pages.

trans-unit.source: Click the Register as a new user link and add a local user with email joe@contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: Click the Register as a new user link and add a local user with email joe@contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: Verify Joe can view the Home, About and Contact pages.
trans-unit.target: Verify Joe can view the Home, About and Contact pages.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>login</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>login</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the CM Demo link and verify you see the data.
trans-unit.target: Click the CM Demo link and verify you see the data.

trans-unit.source: Click an edit link on the page, you will be redirected to the log in page (because a new local user is not added to the canEdit role).
trans-unit.target: Click an edit link on the page, you will be redirected to the log in page (because a new local user is not added to the canEdit role).

trans-unit.source: Log in as user1@contoso.com with password of "P_assw0rd1" (the "0" in "word" is a zero).
trans-unit.target: Log in as user1@contoso.com with password of "P_assw0rd1" (the "0" in "word" is a zero).

trans-unit.source: You will be redirected to the edit page you previously selected.
trans-unit.target: You will be redirected to the edit page you previously selected.

trans-unit.source: If you can't log in with that account and password, try copying the password from the source code and pasting it.
trans-unit.target: If you can't log in with that account and password, try copying the password from the source code and pasting it.

trans-unit.source: If you still can't log in, check the UserName column of the AspNetUsers table to verify user1@contoso.com was added.
trans-unit.target: If you still can't log in, check the UserName column of the AspNetUsers table to verify user1@contoso.com was added.

trans-unit.source: Verify you can make data changes.
trans-unit.target: Verify you can make data changes.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the app to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy the app to Azure

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish from the context menu.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish from the context menu.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish in project context menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish in project context menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Publish Web wizard opens.
trans-unit.target: The Publish Web wizard opens.

trans-unit.source: Click the Settings tab on the left side of the Publish Web dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Click the Settings tab on the left side of the Publish Web dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Click the v icon to select the Remote connection string for ApplicationDbContext and select the ContactManagerNN_db.
trans-unit.target: Click the v icon to select the Remote connection string for ApplicationDbContext and select the ContactManagerNN_db.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Under ContactManagerContext, select Execute Code First Migrations.
trans-unit.target: Under ContactManagerContext, select Execute Code First Migrations.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish.

trans-unit.source: Log in as user1@contoso.com (with password of "P_assw0rd1") and verify you can edit data.
trans-unit.target: Log in as user1@contoso.com (with password of "P_assw0rd1") and verify you can edit data.

trans-unit.source: Log out.
trans-unit.target: Log out.

trans-unit.source: Go to the Google Developers Console and on the Credentials tab update the redirect URIS and JavaScript Orgins to use the Azure URL.
trans-unit.target: Go to the Google Developers Console and on the Credentials tab update the redirect URIS and JavaScript Orgins to use the Azure URL.

trans-unit.source: Log in using Google or Facebook.
trans-unit.target: Log in using Google or Facebook.

trans-unit.source: That will add the Google or Facebook account to the canEdit role.
trans-unit.target: That will add the Google or Facebook account to the canEdit role.

trans-unit.source: If you get an HTTP 400 error with the message The redirect URI in the request: https://contactmanager{my version}.azurewebsites.net/signin-google did not match a registered redirect URI., you'll have to wait until the changes you made are propagated.
trans-unit.target: If you get an HTTP 400 error with the message The redirect URI in the request: https://contactmanager{my version}.azurewebsites.net/signin-google did not match a registered redirect URI., you'll have to wait until the changes you made are propagated.

trans-unit.source: If you get this error after more than a few minutes, verify the URIs are correct.
trans-unit.target: If you get this error after more than a few minutes, verify the URIs are correct.

trans-unit.source: Stop the web app to prevent other people from registering
trans-unit.target: Stop the web app to prevent other people from registering

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, navigate to Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, navigate to Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Right click on the web app and select Stop.
trans-unit.target: Right click on the web app and select Stop.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>stop web app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>stop web app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, from the Azure Portal, you can select the web app, then click the stop icon at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, from the Azure Portal, you can select the web app, then click the stop icon at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>stop web app portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>stop web app portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Remove AddToRoleAsync, Publish, and Test
trans-unit.target: Remove AddToRoleAsync, Publish, and Test

trans-unit.source: Comment out or remove the following code from the ExternalLoginConfirmation method in the Account controller:
trans-unit.target: Comment out or remove the following code from the ExternalLoginConfirmation method in the Account controller:

trans-unit.source: await UserManager.AddToRoleAsync(user.Id, "canEdit");
trans-unit.target: await UserManager.AddToRoleAsync(user.Id, "canEdit");

trans-unit.source: Build the project (which saves the file changes and verifies you don't have any compile errors).
trans-unit.target: Build the project (which saves the file changes and verifies you don't have any compile errors).

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: Click the Start Preview button.
trans-unit.target: Click the Start Preview button.

trans-unit.source: Only the files that need to be updated are deployed.
trans-unit.target: Only the files that need to be updated are deployed.

trans-unit.source: Start the web app from Visual Studio or from the Portal.
trans-unit.target: Start the web app from Visual Studio or from the Portal.

trans-unit.source: You won't be able to publish while the web app is stopped.
trans-unit.target: You won't be able to publish while the web app is stopped.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>start web app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>start web app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Go back to Visual Studio and click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Go back to Visual Studio and click Publish.

trans-unit.source: Your Azure App opens up in your default browser.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure App opens up in your default browser.

trans-unit.source: If you are logged in, log out so you can view the home page as an anonymous user.
trans-unit.target: If you are logged in, log out so you can view the home page as an anonymous user.

trans-unit.source: Click the About link.
trans-unit.target: Click the About link.

trans-unit.source: You'll be redirected to the Log in page.
trans-unit.target: You'll be redirected to the Log in page.

trans-unit.source: Click the Register link on the Log in page and create local account.
trans-unit.target: Click the Register link on the Log in page and create local account.

trans-unit.source: We will use this local account to verify you can access the read only pages but you cannot access pages that change data (which are protected by the canEdit role).
trans-unit.target: We will use this local account to verify you can access the read only pages but you cannot access pages that change data (which are protected by the canEdit role).

trans-unit.source: Later on in the tutorial we will remove local account access.
trans-unit.target: Later on in the tutorial we will remove local account access.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Register</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Register</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Verify you can navigate to the About and Contact pages.
trans-unit.target: Verify you can navigate to the About and Contact pages.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Log off</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Log off</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the CM Demo link to navigate to the Cm controller.
trans-unit.target: Click the CM Demo link to navigate to the Cm controller.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can append Cm to the URL.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can append Cm to the URL.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CM page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CM page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click an Edit link.
trans-unit.target: Click an Edit link.

trans-unit.source: You will be redirected to the log in page.
trans-unit.target: You will be redirected to the log in page.

trans-unit.source: Under Use another service to log in, Click Google or Facebook and log in with the account you previously registered.
trans-unit.target: Under Use another service to log in, Click Google or Facebook and log in with the account you previously registered.

trans-unit.source: (If you're working quickly and your session cookie has not timed out, you will be automatically logged in with the Google or Facebook account you previously used.)
trans-unit.target: (If you're working quickly and your session cookie has not timed out, you will be automatically logged in with the Google or Facebook account you previously used.)

trans-unit.source: Verify you can edit data while logged into that account.
trans-unit.target: Verify you can edit data while logged into that account.

trans-unit.source: Note: You cannot log out of Google from this app and log into a different google account with the same browser.
trans-unit.target: Note: You cannot log out of Google from this app and log into a different google account with the same browser.

trans-unit.source: If you are using one browser, you will have to navigate to Google and log out.
trans-unit.target: If you are using one browser, you will have to navigate to Google and log out.

trans-unit.source: You can log on with another account from the same third party authenticator (such as Google) by using a different browser.
trans-unit.target: You can log on with another account from the same third party authenticator (such as Google) by using a different browser.

trans-unit.source: If you have not filled out the first and last name of your Google account information, a NullReferenceException will occur.
trans-unit.target: If you have not filled out the first and last name of your Google account information, a NullReferenceException will occur.

trans-unit.source: Examine the SQL Azure DB
trans-unit.target: Examine the SQL Azure DB

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, navigate to the ContactDB
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, navigate to the ContactDB

trans-unit.source: Right click on ContactDB and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Right click on ContactDB and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>open in SSOX</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>open in SSOX</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you haven't connected to this database previously, you may be prompted to add a firewall rule to enable access for your current IP address.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't connected to this database previously, you may be prompted to add a firewall rule to enable access for your current IP address.

trans-unit.source: The IP address will be pre-filled.
trans-unit.target: The IP address will be pre-filled.

trans-unit.source: Simply, click Add Firewall Rule to enable access.
trans-unit.target: Simply, click Add Firewall Rule to enable access.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>add firewall rule</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>add firewall rule</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Then, log in to the database with the user name and password that you specified when creating the database.
trans-unit.target: Then, log in to the database with the user name and password that you specified when creating the database.

trans-unit.source: Right click on the AspNetUsers table and select View Data.
trans-unit.target: Right click on the AspNetUsers table and select View Data.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CM page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CM page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note the Id from the Google account you registered with to be in the canEdit role, and the Id of user1@contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: Note the Id from the Google account you registered with to be in the canEdit role, and the Id of user1@contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: These should be the only users in the canEdit role.
trans-unit.target: These should be the only users in the canEdit role.

trans-unit.source: (You'll verify that in the next step.)
trans-unit.target: (You'll verify that in the next step.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CM page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CM page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server Object Explorer, right click on AspNetUserRoles and select View Data.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server Object Explorer, right click on AspNetUserRoles and select View Data.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CM page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CM page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Verify the UserId is from user1@contoso.com and the Google account you registered.
trans-unit.target: Verify the UserId is from user1@contoso.com and the Google account you registered.
